title: The Park Cleanup Puzzle

curriculum.subject: Social-Emotional Learning
learningObjectives: Students will practice taking initiative when discovering problems
Students will demonstrate responsible investigation skills
Students will show ownership in community care

selObjectives: Practice taking responsibility for investigating problems

caselCoverage.self-awareness: Recognizing your role in community care
caselCoverage.self-management: Staying focused when facing unexpected challenges
caselCoverage.relationship-skills: Collaborating with peers and adults to solve problems
caselCoverage.responsible-decision-making: Taking ownership and following through on solutions

intro.text: You arrive at Willow Creek Park on a bright Saturday morning.
It's time for the monthly neighborhood cleanup event.
The park is quiet this early, with morning fog still hanging over the pond.
Mr. Patterson, the retired teacher who organizes these events, usually sets up near the main pavilion.
As you walk toward the usual meeting spot, something catches your eye.
Near the new butterfly garden, the mulch has been scattered everywhere.
Several of the young milkweed plants appear flattened.
You spot Jaylen and Sophie, both regular cleanup volunteers.
They're standing at the edge of the disturbed area with confused expressions.

beats.text: Jaylen shakes his head as you approach.
"This definitely wasn't like this when we left last weekend," he says.
Sophie crouches near one of the damaged plants.
"There are marks in the dirt here," she observes.
You notice a plastic garden trowel lying in the grass a few feet away.
It looks like it came from the cleanup supply bin.

choices.text: Pick up the trowel and examine it more closely
choices.illustrationHint: You reaching for the garden trowel

feedback.encouragement: You showed responsibility by taking initiative to investigate.

choices.text: Ask Jaylen and Sophie what they think caused this damage
choices.illustrationHint: You talking with Jaylen and Sophie

feedback.encouragement: That didn't show responsibility—you asked others instead of taking action.

choices.text: Follow the trail of scattered mulch toward the pond

feedback.encouragement: You showed some initiative by tracking the problem.

beats.text: You hear footsteps on the gravel path behind you.
Mr. Patterson is walking toward the butterfly garden.
He's carrying a stack of trash bags and wearing his bright orange volunteer vest.
He stops short when he sees the state of the garden bed.
"Oh dear," he says, setting down the supplies.
"I had a feeling something like this might have happened."
He explains Mrs. Lee heard strange sounds from this area around sunset yesterday.

choices.text: Ask Mr. Patterson what kind of sounds Mrs. Lee heard
choices.illustrationHint: You asking Mr. Patterson a question

feedback.encouragement: You showed responsibility by seeking important details.

choices.text: Suggest checking if any supplies are missing from the shed

feedback.encouragement: You showed some initiative with a practical suggestion.

choices.text: Wait for Mr. Patterson to tell you what to do next

feedback.encouragement: That didn't show responsibility—you waited instead of taking action.

beats.text: Mr. Patterson tells you Mrs. Lee described hearing digging sounds.
She also thought she might have heard animal noises.
You notice movement in the tall grass at the edge of the butterfly garden.
The grass sways back and forth, though there isn't much breeze.
Sophie whispers and points toward a small gap in the ornamental fence.
You can hear soft rustling sounds coming from the tall grass.

choices.text: Walk toward the tall grass to see what's hiding there
choices.illustrationHint: You walking toward the tall grass

feedback.encouragement: You showed responsibility by investigating thoroughly.

choices.text: Stay where you are and call out gently to whatever is in the grass
choices.illustrationHint: You calling out while staying at a safe distance

feedback.encouragement: You showed some care with a cautious approach.

choices.text: Wait patiently to see if something emerges on its own

feedback.encouragement: That didn't show responsibility—you waited instead of taking action.

ending.text: A family of raccoons waddles out from the tall grass.
One larger adult and three smaller ones pause when they see the group.
They slowly amble toward the fence gap and disappear into the wooded area.
Mr. Patterson chuckles and scratches his head.
"Well, that solves our mystery," he says.
Jaylen suggests adding chicken wire around the base of the plants.
The morning cleanup begins with an unexpected new project to tackle.
